results.title: Remedial programming (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: James M. Smith and Davidson Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Specific learning disabilities”.
Shows the combination of three different styles of remedying specific learning difficulties in a special classroom. Practical solutions are offered which are applicable to “normal” classrooms. Suitable for teacher/tertiary levels.

results.title: Rembrandt: painter of man
results.creator_credit: Bert Haanstra, Bert Haanstra Film Productions and Coronet Instructional Films
results.brief_description: Presents selected canvases gathered from twenty-nine museums in twelve countries. These paintings highlight Rembrandt’s use of light and shadow, and his ability to express compassion for his subjects.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Bert Haanstra, Bert Haanstra Film Productions and Coronet Instructional Films

results.title: Rembrandt: draughtsman
results.creator_credit: Nederlandse Omroep Stichting, Rijksmuseum Amsterdam, Hans Nieman, Tina De Vrij and Kees van Langeraad
results.brief_description: The paintings of Dutch 17th century painter Rembrandt van Rijn, are world famous, but a large number of his beautiful drawings have never been seen by the public. This film explores this rich oeuvre, setting it in the context of Rembrandt’s life, his work, his contemporaries and the society of 17th century Holland.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Nederlandse Omroep Stichting, Rijksmuseum Amsterdam, Hans Nieman, Tina De Vrij and Kees van Langeraad

results.title: Rembrandt. Part III: beyond art
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Rembrandt”.
Sir Kenneth Clark, eminent British art authority introduces the series of three films on the life and work of the Dutch painter, Rembrandt. In this last part, it shows how Rembrandt retained the moment of vision in all his paintings, and illustrates his marvellous ability for detail as exemplified in the fleyed ox. His many portraits show his intense self-insight and his humorous acceptance of life. His wonderful sense of balance and space is illustrated especially in “The Old Woman” and a group of “Important Men in Amsterdam”.
results.description:

group_siblings.title: Rembrandt. Part II: life and art

results.title: Rembrandt. Part II: life and art
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Rembrandt”.
Sir Kenneth Clark introduces a series of three films on the life and work of the Dutch painter, Rembrandt. At the height of his success in 1642 Rembrandt amassed a large fortune, which he fritted away before his wife’s death. There were difficult years ahead. Discusses Rembrandt’s greater master of character; his increased, more “dramatic” interest in landscape. By 1664 his use of the classic rather than the baroque design marked a turning point in his career.

results.title: Rembrandt. Part I: success story
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Rembrandt”.
Sir Kenneth Clark, eminent British art authority introduces the series of three films on the life and work of the Dutch painter, Rembrandt. Rembrandt’s early life and work are described in this first film. He was born in Leyden in 1606; his family recognised his talent and sent him to Amsterdam to study. His brilliant drawing and skilful use of oils established his reputation. In 1631 he settled in Amsterdam and married Saskia van Uylenborch three years later. He painted his wife many times and the period of his early married life contains many happy and light-hearted pictures.

results.title: Rembrandt's - The Three Crosses
results.creator_credit: Balfour Films, Arts Council of Great Britain and Dudley Shaw Ashton
results.brief_description: A detailed account of the engraving of the original plate for Rembrandt’s celebrated print; the artist’s experimental use of different papers and methods of inking, and the later re-working of the plate. Commentary written and spoken by Christopher White.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Balfour Films, Arts Council of Great Britain and Dudley Shaw Ashton
